data.title: Greed review — a furious, funny Philip Green satire

data.text:
★★★★☆

Film buffs will undoubtedly describe this, Michael Winterbottom’s latest project, in gruesome Franglais, as a “movie à clef”. Borrowing from French literary history (see roman à clef), the term applies to a film that is a thinly veiled portrait, often satirical, of a real-life figure; think of John Travolta’s version of Bill Clinton in Primary Colors, Orson Welles doing an loose approximation of William Randolph Hearst in Citizen Kane, or even Meryl Streep’s glacial take on Anna Wintour in The Devil Wears Prada. These are satirical movies about specific people that are not, in only the most strict legal sense, about specific people. Wink wink. Nudge nudge.

Greed is a movie à clef “about” the high street billionaire Philip Green. The
